prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
IRS 48 is well situated on the southern sky for ALMA observations, as demonstrated by the earlier Cycle 0 observations. The configuration is chosen based on the line observations as a compromise between the highest spatial resolution required for our science goals and the expected strength of the emission. We observe the 12CO 3-2 line at the highest spatial resolution of ~0.1'' in order to measure the density drop within 20 AU (see Figure 1), as the emission of the isotopologues is no longer detectable at this high spatial resolution.
In order to have sufficient velocity resolution and maximize the continuum sensitivity, the basebands containing lines are set to FDM mode with 0.25 km/s resolution (282 kHz in Band 7). In addition to the CO isotopologues we target several other diagnostic lines, which have been chosen based on the frequency of the CO line. The 12CO 3-2 frequency of 345 GHz combines well with the HCO+ 4-3 (357 GHz), CS 7-6 (343 GHz) and HCN 4-3 (355 GHz) lines. The detection or non-detection of the targeted lines will constrain several physical and chemical properties in the disk.
The required sensitivity is based on the predictions of our gas model for IRS 48 for the CO line. Assuming typical weather conditions (0.9 mm for Band 7), we find a rms level of 3.2 mJy/beam per 1 km/s channel for 30 minutes on source integration. Since the main goal of these observations is to constrain delta20 (the density drop within 20 AU), our S/N demands are based on this value (see also Figure 1). Our model calculations for 12CO 3-2 reach a maximum of 0.38 Jy/beam inside the 20 AU gas hole for the highest value of delta20 of 8E-2, and 0.015 Jy/beam for delta20 of 2.5E-3. Thus a S/N of ~120 is reached for the highest delta20, down to S/N=5 for delta20=2.5E-3, or a depth of a factor 400. This range of testable values for delta20 thus indicate planet masses from less than 1 Jupiter mass up to at least 5 Jupiter masses in comparison with hydro-models.
The continuum bandwidth is 1875 MHz, resulting in rms levels of 86 microJy/beam. According to our dust trap model predictions, the peak S/N on this high spatial resolution continuum is thus ~1000. This is sufficient to measure the position of the dust trap down to a precision of 10% of the resolution, i.e. 0.012'', as there is a bright phase calibrator (J1625-243) within 1.5 degrees nearby. This means that the expected shift of the dust trap along its orbit of 0.09'' can be readily measured over a 10 year period. For measuring the azimuthal distribution of the dust disk on larger scales, the data will be combined with the continuum of Science Goal 1, resulting in a combined bandwidth of 5.6 GHz and a rms level of 46 microJy, or peak S/N of 1300. This will be sufficient to measure the azimuthal extent to an accuracy of a few degrees.
In the requested configuration, a single pointing will filter out the outer disk emission beyond 2.6'' scales, but as the full disk size was found to be no larger than 160 AU in radius (Bruderer et al. 2014) additional short baselines are not required.
The team contains all the necessary expertise to reduce, analyze and model the data quickly. Our team members have been pioneers in millimeter interferometry, gas-grain dynamics, dust evolution theory and thermo-chemical models of transitional disks, and have experience with hydro models.

IRS 48 is well situated on the southern sky for ALMA observations, as demonstrated by the earlier Cycle 0 observations. The configuration is chosen based on the line observations as a compromise between the highest spatial resolution required for our science goals and the expected strength of the emission. The isotopologues 13CO and C18O will still be detected at the ~0.2'' resolution.
In order to have sufficient velocity resolution and maximize the continuum sensitivity, the basebands containing lines are set to FDM mode with 0.2 km/s resolution (488 kHz in Band 9 , with a bandwidth of 469 MHz). In addition to the CO isotopologues we target several other diagnostic lines, which have been chosen based on the frequencies of the CO lines. The 13CO 6-5 line is combined with C18O 6-5 and H2CO 9_{1,8}-8_{1,7} (674 GHz), as this transition of H2CO was already detected in the Cycle 0 observations (van der Marel et al. subm.) but only up to 8sigma (sigma=30 mJy/beam per 1 km/s channel). With the sensitivity of the requested observations (sigma=13 mJy/beam per 1 km/s channel) we can increase the S/N to 18sigma and measure the spatial distribution of the H2CO with higher accuracy. The fourth spectral window is set to 1875 MHz bandwidth for a larger continuum coverage and the possibility of serendipitous line detection with 0.5 km/s resolution .
The required sensitivity is based on the predictions of our gas model for IRS 48 for the CO lines. Assuming typical weather conditions (0.5 mm for Band 9), we find a rms level of 13 mJy/beam per 1 km/s for 60 minutes on source integration. Since the main goal of these observations is to constrain delta60 (the density drop within 60 AU), our S/N demands are based on this value. Our model calculations for 13CO 6-5 reach a maximum of 1.5 Jy/beam inside the 60 AU gas hole for the highest value of delta60 of 8E-1, and 0.1 Jy/beam for delta60 of 2.5E-2. Thus a S/N of ~115 is reached for the highest delta60, down to S/N=10 for delta60=2.5E-2, or a depth of a factor 40. For C18O a peak S/N of 10 is reached. The range of testable values for delta60 thus indicate planet masses from less than 1 Jupiter mass up to at least 2 Jupiter masses. For the outer disk, the 13CO 6-5 emission is ~0.5 Jy/beam, thus a S/N of almost 38, which will allow the measurement of azimuthal variations in the gas up to a factor 3 (as used in our dust trap model in van der Marel et al. 2013), with a S/N>10. The combination of the 6-5 with the 3-2 transition of Science Goal 1 will allow to distinguish between variations in temperature and density, as these both result in differences in intensiy.
The continuum bandwidth is 4.7 GHz, resulting in a rms levels of 300 microJy/beam. According to our dust trap model predictions, the peak S/N on the continuum is thus ~1000. Our ALMA Cycle 0 data had a continuum rms of ~800 microJy/beam and the emission in the northern part of the ring was found to be ~2sigma along several beams (van der Marel et al. 2013). With the higher S/N of the Band 9 continuum in Cycle 2, the significance of this marginal detection can be checked and the real azimuthal contrast can be quantified to at most a factor of 2 higher.
In the requested configuration, a single pointing will filter out the outer disk emission beyond 2.8'' scales, but as the full disk size was found to be no larger than 160 AU in radius (Bruderer et al. 2014) additional short baselines are not required.
The team contains all the necessary expertise to reduce, analyze and model the data quickly. Our team members have been pioneers in millimeter interferometry, gas-grain dynamics, dust evolution theory and thermo-chemical models of transitional disks, and have experience with hydro models.

IRS 48 is well situated on the southern sky for ALMA observations, as demonstrated by the earlier Cycle 0 observations. Apart from the continuum emission that is measured along the lines targeted in the Band 7 and Band 9 observations, we request Band 4 continuum observations to measure the distribution of the larger 6 millimeter grains, to constrain the trapping efficiency. Band 4 (2 millimeter) is the longest wavelength where the high dust concentration can still be azimuthally resolved in the highest resolution of the C34-7 configuration. We set one of the basebands of the correlator centered at the DCO+ 2-1 line at 0.3 km/s resolution, and the other basebands at continuum (1875 MHz bandwidth per band) for a larger continuum coverage and the possibility of serendipitous line detection with 2.5 km/s resolution.
The required sensitivity is based on the total continuum flux for IRS 48. Assuming typical weather conditions (2.7 mm for Band 4), we find a rms level of 4.7 mJy/beam/channel for 30 minute on source integration. The continuum bandwidth is 5.9 GHz, resulting in a rms levels of 25 microJy. The total flux at 150 GHz is estimated through measured fluxes at 690, 345, 230 and 34 GHz to be ~13 mJy. According to our dust trap model predictions, the peak S/N on the continuum is thus ~600. This will be sufficient to measure the azimuthal extent to an accuracy of 10 degrees.
In the requested configuration, a single pointing will filter out the outer disk emission beyond 6.1'' scales, but as the full disk size was found to be no larger than 160 AU in radius (Bruderer et al. 2014) additional short baselines are not required.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Planets form in disks of gas and dust around young stars, but little is known about their formation and properties at this early stage. In ALMA Cycle 0 we discovered a major asymmetric dust structure at 60 AU in the transition disk Oph IRS48 indicative of a dust trap which may be the site of planetesimal formation. Our Band 9 12CO 6-5 data also hint at density drops (signatures of one or more embedded planets) inside 60 AU. We propose here higher angular resolution and deeper observations of this fascinating disk, targeting the 13CO and C18O isotopologues of the 3-2 and 6-5 transitions in Band 7 and 9 at 0.2'' to measure the depth of the gap inside 60 AU and quantify any azimuthal asymmetries in the gas in the 60-100 region of the dust trap. We also request 12CO 3-2 observations at 0.12'' to measure the depth of the gas in the 20 AU gap. These measurements will give us direct insight in the properties of potential planets, their formation process and feedback on the disk. Finally, we will measure the wavelength-dependent azimuthal extent of the dust trap to test our proposed mechanism for the dust trap through combined observations of the Band 7, Band 9 and Band 4 continuum.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This proposal continues the analysis of the gas and dust in transition disk Oph IRS 48, following upon our successful ALMA Cycle 0 program 2011.0.00635.S.
